title: 113_s2956
content: The "Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014" is cited as the short title. It amends the Communications Act of 1934 to include the availability of whitelist services. The "Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014" defines key terms such as voice service, exempt entity, and whitelist. The "Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014" defines a whitelist as a list of approved telephone numbers for incoming calls, requires voice service providers to offer whitelist options to subscribers, and outlines the treatment of non-approved numbers. The "Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014" requires voice service providers to process telephone numbers of exempt entities based on subscriber preferences for whitelists, allowing limitations on incoming call connections without being considered blocking traffic or an unjust practice. Providers must allow subscribers to designate at least 10 telephone numbers on the whitelist free of charge. The "Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014" mandates voice service providers to allow subscribers to designate a minimum of 10 telephone numbers on a whitelist free of charge. Exempt entities' numbers are not counted towards this limit. Section 232 of the Communications Act of 1934, added by the Act, will be effective 2 years after enactment. SEC. 233. AUTHENTICATION OF CALL ORIGINATION. This section amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require authentication of call origination. The Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014 mandates the development of authentication standards by the Commission for voice service providers to validate calling party numbers and caller identification information. This ensures secure assurance of call origin for subscribers. The Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014 requires voice service providers to adopt authentication standards for validating calling party numbers and caller identification information. Providers allocated telephone numbers in the United States must comply with these standards. SEC. 4. EXPANDING AND CLARIFYING PROHIBITION ON INACCURATE CALLER ID INFORMATION. The amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 expands the coverage of voice services to include text messages. It clarifies that the prohibition on inaccurate caller ID information applies to calls from outside the United States if the recipient is within the country. The amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 expands the coverage of voice services to include text messages, defining a text message as a real-time message transmitted or received by a device identified by a telephone number. The amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 expands the coverage of voice services to include text messaging services, which are defined as services that permit the transmission or receipt of text messages. The Act does not affect the FCC's authority to interpret the term "call" to include text messages or any rules related to the Telephone Consumer Protection Act or the CAN-SPAM Act. The Federal Communications Commission must create regulations within 18 months of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments. The amendments will become effective 6 months after the regulations are prescribed.
